name: Purchased goods and services
Emissions calculation methodology: To calculate the footprints of the more than 70,000 products that we sell, we developed a pioneering analysis model that enabled us to group products together by their similar material and environmental profiles. These groups were then assigned to representative cradle to gate carbon footprints using the physical mass or volume of the products wesold in the reference year. We then added our direct footprint data to include all emissions associated with retail distribution and sales, and finally allocated UK household emissions based on our market share to capture downstream customer impacts. The blending of bottom up (cradle-to-gate, Tesco emissions) and top-down (customer use and disposal) methodologies allowed us to create a complete lifecycle value chain footprint using the best available data. Consistent with the Greenhouse Gas Protocol Product Standard, we have used primary data for all of our owned and controlled operations. As a retailer, this means that it was a comparatively small proportion approximately 5% of our overall footprint.
explanation: Tesco conducted more than 1,000 product-specific carbon footprint analyses using primary data from our supply chain to the PAS 2050 standard. These product-level studies were grouped into 'representative footprints' to extend to similar product groups. Those products that were not assessed using our own supply chain data were completed by using credible third party studies. The UK supply chain footprint was then extrapolated to the full Group using sales floor area. We estimate that approximately 20% of our Group emissions are therefore using direct supply chain data in a relevant supply chain.

name: Capital goods
explanation: We believe that we can have a greater impact working with our suppliers to reduce the carbon emissions in the products that we sell, rather than the capital goods we use, as these are much higher. We used Defra's 2017 conversion factors to calculate well-to-tank and transmission and distribution loss emissions.

name: Fuel-and-energy-related activities
Emissions calculation methodology: The total electricity and gas consumption data in each country was multiplied by the relevant Scope 3 emission factor for well-to-tank, and transmission and distribution, to determine the emissions amount.
explanation: We used Defra's 2017 conversion factors to calculate well-to-tank and transmission and distribution loss emissions.

name: Business travel
Emissions calculation methodology: We collect business travel data across all our markets, including air, car, taxi and rail data. This activity data is then converted to emissions using relevant emission factors.
explanation: We used Defra's 2017 conversion factors applied to business travel data. All data has been supplied by our travel agents or employee expense forms.

name: Employee commuting
explanation: Rough calculations show that this is immaterial compared to the carbon impact of the products we sell. We believe that we have a greater impact working with our suppliers to reduce the carbon emissions in the products that we sell, rather than our employee commuting.

name: Upstream leased assets
explanation: Tesco follows the operational control approach under the WRI/WBCSD GHG Protocol. Therefore, we include the emissions from any buildings that we lease for Tesco use in our Scope 1 or 2 emissions.

name: Downstream transportation and distribution
explanation: For Tesco, this category would relate to the emissions caused by customers or by third parties transporting sold products back to customers' homes. We estimate that this would be less than the emissions involved in upstream transportation and distribution as customers generally buy products from a Tesco store within a few miles from their home. As, we believe this is relatively immaterial compared to our other Scope 3 emissions, this is not a priority for us to focus on at the moment. All Tesco grocery home delivery is included in our Scope 1 and 2 emissions

name: Processing of sold products
explanation: This category is not relevant for Tesco as we do not sell intermediate products. We sell products direct to the consumer for their own use.

name: Downstream leased assets
explanation: Rough calculations show that the GHG emissions associated with our downstream leased assets are much less than the GHG emissions of our own operations and of the products we sell, which is where we are focusing our activity to reduce Scope 3 emissions.

name: Franchises
explanation: This category is not relevant for Tesco as it is currently immaterial. Currently we only have a few franchise stores of F&F, Tesco's clothing brand, in the Middle East. These produce only a small amount of emissions that are immaterial when compared to other emissions.

name: Investments
explanation: This category is not relevant for Tesco as it is designed primarily for private financial institutions. Tesco does have a retail bank but this provides services for non business customers such as personal loans and mortgages.

explanation: The range of emissions sources listed in this table represents all emissions sources of significance for the Tesco group. No further upstream emissions are relevant to our assessment.
